title: Introductory lecture to sampling and sample pre-treatment techniques

author: Marko Štrok, Reaktorski center, Institut "Jožef Stefan"

segmentation: Hello, my name is Marko and in this lecture I will explain basics of sampling and sample pretreatment techniques.
Sampling is the most important part of each procedure, as if we are sampling samples in our own way, we cannot repair this in the later stages of the procedure.
Therefore, care should be taken.
How to take samples?
We can sample for instance, water sediments, soil, biological materials like grass, lichens or food items.
The most important thing is that we take a representative sample for the purpose we want to achieve.
For instance, if we want to get impression of radionuclide content to formant, taking one sample in a month is probably not sufficient.
If we sample soil from large field taking single sample at one spot will not be representative for whole field.
Other important thing is to consider that we don't contaminate or samples during sampling and to prevent cross contamination.

Usually we are dealing with very low activity concentrations and 1st requisite is to pre concentrate samples.
This can be done mostly by coprecipitation of radionuclides or evaporation of samples.
We can Co precipitate any clients, usually by adding stable carrier such as iron manganese lead or calcium and precipitated in alkaline solutions.
The nuclides and other elements tend to be coprecipitated with such carriers which enable pre concentration of radionuclides from several liters to several MLS.
Which enables easier handling and separation, so premium clients afterwards.
We should not forget to add appropriate tracer for already in client of interest to be able to trace radiochemical recovery of the whole separation procedure.
For biological materials we have to divide or sample to specific organs or parts depending on the purpose of the analysis.
For example.
Fish can be divided to muscle bonds, liver and spleen, plants on leaves, shots and roots.
This is advisable to do as soon as possible after sampling or store samples frozen.
Then we dry the sample to remove water from them to be suitable for further steps.
